search_information.query_displayed: The Downside of Social Closure: Brokerage, Parental Influence, and Delinquency among African American Boys Mangino, William Sociology of Education

organic_results.title: The downside of social closure: Brokerage, parental influence, and delinquency among African American boys
organic_results.snippet: Building on the literature that stresses the social capital advantages of open and diffuse social networks, this article shows that African American boys who are a social bridge across two or more large but cohesive peer groups are less delinquent than are their counterparts who are members of a single peer group. Statistical interaction terms reveal that this decrease in delinquency can be attributed to the increased influence of parents among social bridges. The article concludes that the network form of the adolescent society …

publication_info.summary: W Mangino - Sociology of Education, 2009 - journals.sagepub.com
